title: Importance of Sufficient Output Saturation Sound Pressure Level at 90 dB on Hearing Aids
chief_complaint: Speech sounds too soft in most situations other than very quiet ones. Recognizing speech in a noisy background requires greater effort because speech and noise seem all mingled together.

problem_summary.onset: 1 week after fitting new hearing aids.
problem_summary.course: Acute dissatisfaction following a switch from BTE to RIC devices.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Lack of loudness, muffled sound quality, poor speech recognition in noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty functioning in new job as an engineer; inability to separate speech from noise.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient desires cosmetic upgrade (smaller devices) while maintaining auditory performance for his career.

history.present_illness: Patient is a long-time hearing aid user who recently upgraded from 10-year-old Widex Diva 9 BTEs to new Widex CLEAR 440 C4-Passion RICs for cosmetic reasons. Despite initial satisfaction, he returned after 1 week reporting muffled sound and poor performance in noise.
history.otologic_history: Flat 60 dB HL sensorineural hearing loss since childhood.
history.prior_management: Wore skeleton nonvented earmolds with BTEs since age 3. Previous aids: Widex ES8 BTEs, then Widex Diva 9 BTEs (OSPL90 125 dB SPL).
history.patient_goals: Wanted to upgrade technology for a new job as an engineer but insisted on cosmetically appealing RIC devices (C4-Passion) against the audiologist's initial recommendation for BTEs.

tests.name: Hearing Instrument Verification
tests.key_findings: Simulated frequency output of the new C4-Passion matched the previous Diva 9 at input levels of 50 dB and 65 dB SPL. However, OSPL90 was significantly lower in the new device (108 dB SPL vs 125 dB SPL).

numeric_results.C4_Passion_OSPL90: 108 dB SPL (typically <103 dB SPL in real ear)

tests.name: Speech-in-noise (HINT)
tests.key_findings: Comparison of previous aids (Diva 9), current problem aids (C4-Passion), and proposed alternative (C4-FS). Noise at 70 dB SPL. Lower RTS indicates better performance.

numeric_results.Estimated_Improvement: 30-50% sentence recognition improvement with C4-FS vs C4-Passion

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient has a flat 60 dB HL sensorineural hearing loss and was unsuccessfully fitted with low-power RIC devices (C4-Passion) which had insufficient OSPL90 (108 dB SPL) compared to his previous BTEs (125 dB SPL). This resulted in saturation/clipping of loud speech peaks, causing muffled sound and significantly degraded speech-in-noise performance (+2 dB SNR on HINT). Comparative testing demonstrated that a higher-power RIC (C4-FS) restored and slightly improved performance (-3 dB SNR).
counseling_points: The 'muffled' sound you are experiencing is because the smaller C4-Passion hearing aids cannot handle the loud peaks of speech, effectively 'clipping' the sound.
Your previous hearing aids had a much higher maximum power output (OSPL90), which your hearing loss requires for clarity in noise.

We recommend switching to the Clear Fusion (C4-FS) model with a power receiver. It is still cosmetically discreet but provides the power necessary to match the loudness and clarity of your previous devices.
Our testing shows the Fusion model improves your ability to hear in noise by roughly 30-50% compared to the Passion model you are currently trying.
notes_for_actor: You are an engineer, so you are analytical and understand technical explanations, but you are also very conscious of cosmetics.
You are frustrated that 'newer technology' sounds worse than your 10-year-old hearing aids.
